task.taskName: Model a full wave voltage doubler

construction: This voltage doubler is driven by an AC voltage source,as shown above.  Assume the AC source is 60 volts at its peak and has a wavelength of 18 ms.  Nodes for this source have been given to you.  The capacitors are both 0.068 Farads, and the load is 10,000 Ohms.  The diodes have a knee voltage of 0.7 volts, which you can include insider their expressions to avoid the clutter of separate knee voltage nodes.  Finish the model and view the graph of the output voltage.
incremental: This voltage doubler is driven by an AC voltage source,as shown above.  Assume the AC source is 60 volts at its peak and has a wavelength of 18 ms.  Nodes for this source have been given to you.  The capacitors are both 0.068 Farads, and the load is 10,000 ohms.  The diodes have a knee voltage of 0.7 volts, which is included in their expressions.
execution: This voltage doubler is driven by an AC voltage source,as shown above.  Assume the AC source is 60 volts at its peak and has a wavelength of 18 ms.  Nodes for this source have been given to you.  The capacitors are both 0.068 Farads, and the load is 10,000 ohms.  The diodes have a knee voltage of 0.7 volts, which is included in their expressions.
waveform: This voltage doubler is driven by an AC voltage source,as shown above.  Assume the AC source is 60 volts at its peak and has a wavelength of 18 ms.  Nodes for this source have been given to you.  The capacitors are both 0.068 Farads, and the load is 10,000 ohms.  The diodes have a knee voltage of 0.7 volts, which is included in their expressions.

givenModelNodes.name: AC input V
givenModelNodes.explanation: Voltage with respect to ground of point A, the top of the transformer's secondary winding.

givenModelNodes.name: Max input V
givenModelNodes.description: Height of peak of sinewave of AC input

givenModelNodes.name: wavelength
givenModelNodes.description: Duration of full cycle of sinewave

givenModelNodes.name: V across D1 if open
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage across diode D1 if it is reversed biased

givenModelNodes.name: V across C1
givenModelNodes.explanation: When charged, voltage is positive on top.

givenModelNodes.name: Charging C1
givenModelNodes.description: Change in voltage on C1 due to charging

givenModelNodes.name: Discharging C1
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage change on C1 due to discharging

givenModelNodes.name: V across C2
givenModelNodes.explanation: When charged, voltage is positive on top and negative on bottom. u00a0u00a0

givenModelNodes.name: Charging C2
givenModelNodes.description: Change in voltage on C2 due to charging

givenModelNodes.name: V across D2 if open
givenModelNodes.description: Voltage across diode D2 if reverse biased
givenModelNodes.explanation: The top of C2 is positive when it is charged and this side is attached to the bottom of the transformer. u00a0So when the AC signal is high, this is like having two batteries in series, so their voltages sum.

givenModelNodes.name: V applied across C2
givenModelNodes.explanation: Usually, the expression is "AC input - V across D" u00a0and this is applied from bottom to top like C1. u00a0However, the wires are reversed for C2, so we use -(AC input - V across D2) which simplifies to "V across D2 - AC input.

schemas.name: Full Wave Voltage Doubler Behavior
schemas.nodes: id4, id5, id20, id19, id18, id17, id16, id15, id14, id13, id12, id11, id10, id9, id8, id7, id6
